questions.question_text: During user acceptance testing, a defect is logged by a user from a department that did not participate in the requirements analysis. To avoid this situation and minimize impact on the project, the user should have been:

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. identified as a stakeholder as part of the stakeholder analysis would have helped avoid this situation and minimize the impact on the project. Stakeholder analysis is the process of identifying the stakeholders in a project and analyzing their needs, interests, and influence on the project. By identifying all of the stakeholders in the project, the project team can ensure that their needs and concerns are taken into account during the planning and execution of the project. This can help minimize the risk of defects being logged during user acceptance testing, as all of the stakeholders will have had an opportunity to review and provide feedback on the project requirements.

choices.A: interviewed to understand how the user’s work would be impacted.
choices.D: identified as a stakeholder as part of the stakeholder analysis.
choices.B: involved in the development and sign-off of the business requirements.
choices.C: given the opportunity to review the user acceptance test scripts.

questions.question_text: When faced with a tight timeline, the project sponsor suggests that the project team start development without creating traceability artifacts. What should the business analyst do?

choices.A: Negotiate for a quick approval of a reduced set of traceability artifacts.
choices.B: Explain the value of requirements traceability.
choices.D: Start development activities without traceability items.
choices.C: Eliminate traceability activities for the project.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B
When A occurs, there is no traceability for the project at all.

Selected Answer: B
B. Explain the value of requirements traceability.

The business analyst should educate the project sponsor on the importance and benefits of requirements traceability. Traceability artifacts can help ensure that all requirements are addressed and implemented correctly, reducing the risk of scope creep and rework. Additionally, they provide a record of decisions and changes made throughout the project, making it easier to manage and maintain the project in the long term. The business analyst should also suggest alternative solutions to shorten the timeline, such as reducing the scope or increasing the resources.

Selected Answer: C
C. Traceability matrix.

A traceability matrix is a tool that links requirements to their origin and traces them throughout the project lifecycle. By using a traceability matrix, a business analyst can ensure that all requirements are accounted for and delivered as stated. If an approved requirement has been missed during testing, the business analyst can trace back to see where the requirement was introduced and take appropriate action to ensure it is implemented.

questions.question_text: A business analyst assigned to review test output for a project realizes that an approved requirement has been missed. Which technique could the business analyst have used to ensure that requirements were delivered as stated?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The best course of action is:

C. Compare reported defects with user acceptance test results.

Explanation:
Before escalating or taking further steps, it's essential to validate the reported defects against the user acceptance test (UAT) results. This ensures the reported issues were not already addressed or accepted as part of the agreed solution during UAT.
This step helps identify whether the defects are new, previously known but accepted by the customer, or overlooked during the UAT phase.
If gaps are identified after this comparison, further actions like involving end users (option D) or escalating (option A) can be considered appropriately.

Selected Answer: D
D. Involve the end users and plan a new round of acceptance tests to check the gaps.

It is important to address reported defects to ensure customer satisfaction and minimize negative impacts on the business. Involving the end users in identifying and validating the reported defects can help ensure that the issues are properly addressed. Planning a new round of acceptance tests can help identify any gaps and ensure that the solution meets the customer's requirements.

choices.D: Involve the end users and plan a new round of acceptance tests to check the gaps.
choices.B: Do nothing since the solution is now the responsibility of the operations manager.
choices.A: Escalate the issue to the project manager since the acceptance was given by the customer.
choices.C: Compare reported defects with user acceptance test results.

questions.question_text: After implementation of the product, the customer reports defects. What is the best course of action to take?

choices.B: Scope modeling, Ishikawa diagram, and/or the Five Whys
choices.A: Root cause analysis, fishbone diagram, and/or the Five Whys
choices.D: Cause and effect diagram, brainstorming, and/or the Five Whys
choices.C: Root cause analysis, problem tracking, and/or benchmarking

questions.question_text:
A company has just finished the development work for a new software sales tracking application and is in the process of validating that the new application meets all of the acceptance criteria defined for the business requirements. During the validation process, a stakeholder discovers that the application does not provide the selection criteria needed to produce the sales volume reporting required by the company’s financial department. The business analyst for the project determines that the selection criteria needed was not specified in the system requirements or design specifications.
Which of the following tools and/or techniques might be used by the business analyst to determine how the selection criteria requirement was missed?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Root cause analysis, fishbone diagram, and/or the Five Whys.

Root cause analysis is a technique used to identify the underlying cause of a problem or issue. The fishbone diagram, also known as an Ishikawa diagram, is a tool used to identify potential causes of a problem. The Five Whys technique involves asking "why" questions to identify the root cause of a problem. In this scenario, the business analyst could use one or more of these tools and techniques to identify why the selection criteria requirement was missed and to determine what steps can be taken to prevent similar issues from arising in the future.

comments.content: Fishbone is a form of RCA which is why that answer doesn't fit as well as the other.
